Comments_List: I learned important skills for programming dynamic models.

Almost every topic touched upon in this class was new to me. I learned so many skills related to programming:
-Learning how to write well-structured code 
-Learning how to write functions, subroutines and call them in your code 
-Numerical methods including:
*Function approximation
*Optimization
*Root-finding
*Finite differences
*Quadrature
*etc.
-Learning techniques that are helpful for solving economic models, especially value function iteration, etc.
The course is really good. You can learn a lot with the problem sets and the final project.

I think that this course was great. I am looking forward to being able to apply the skills learned in my future research and course work. 
Strengths:
-Introduction of numerical tools and topics so that the foundation is laid for future exploration into topics
-Speed and clarity of information presented
-Quality of the homework assignments (they were great at giving an opportunity to really figure out how things work)

Weakness:
-The final project was a bit daunting. Maybe a few examples early on in the course of past work done would be helpful as people try to understand the amount of work expected of them.

Definitely. Anyone interested in pursuing a graduate program in economics would benefit from this course. 
Even if graduate school is not the target, I can imagine programming skills - generally - would be useful in future work.
